nodes.text: Government debt (internal vs external) changes the long-run competitive equilibrium in a neoclassical two-period-lived agent growth model and thereby affects individual utility

Model method: discrete-time infinite-horizon economy with constant-returns aggregate production F(K,L)=L f(k), two-period-lived individuals with utility U(c1,c2), no depreciation, population growth rate n, and competitive markets determining wages and interest
Assumption: government debt has one-period maturity, debt-labor ratio is kept constant (debt grows at rate n), and taxes to finance interest are lump-sum on the young

Central planner benchmark: Golden Age Path maximizes individual lifetime utility subject to resource constraint; Golden Rule capital-labor ratio satisfies marginal product of capital equals population growth (f'(k)=n)
Competitive equilibrium may be dynamically inefficient: the market equilibrium interest rate can differ from the growth rate so capital-labor ratio can exceed Golden Rule
Household optimization: given wage wt and one-period interest rt+1, individuals choose consumption and saving; aggregate saving S(w,r) determines supply of capital
Capital market equilibrium: rt+1 = f'(S(wt,rt+1)/(1+n)) and factor-price frontier relates w and r via production (w = f(k)-k f'(k)) allowing derivation of equilibrium dynamics and stability

Analytic example: Cobb-Douglas production and CRRA-like log utility yields closed-form saving and equilibrium expressions illustrating that equilibrium r can be greater or less than n depending on parameters
External debt effect on domestic economy arises solely through taxes needed to finance interest not covered by increased debt; taxes per worker = (r - n) g1

Internal debt differs because government floats domestic debt on demand side of capital market: equilibrium condition includes government borrowing and internal debt substitutes for physical capital in portfolios

Stability and comparative statics: under assumed relative slopes of supply and demand in capital market, changes in taxes or debt shift the s(w,r) or i1 curves and move long-run r and w; dr/dg sign depends on (r - n) and slopes

Result for external debt (normal/efficient case where r>n): external debt raises equilibrium interest rate away from Golden Rule via tax-induced supply reduction, reduces disposable lifetime consumption, lowers savings and capital, and thereby reduces long-run individual utility

Result for internal debt: internal debt combines tax effects like external debt plus an additional substitution effect that replaces physical capital with government debt in private portfolios, further reducing capital stock and (in the efficient case) lowering individual utility; overall effect sign may differ in inefficient case

Mechanism decomposition claim: welfare effects can be split into (a) tax-finance effects common to internal and external debt and (b) allocation effects on factor payments arising from shifts in capital market demand or supply; the latter determine whether r moves toward or away from n and thus whether utility rises or falls

Debt swap (retire external debt by issuing internal debt) always raises equilibrium interest rate (under primary stability assumptions) because government becomes net demander, reducing capital-labor ratio; in efficient case this swap lowers utility unambiguously, while in inefficient case sign is ambiguous

Conclusion: In the standard efficient competitive case (r>n) both external and internal debt reduce long-run individual utility, internal debt usually causes a larger decline due to portfolio substitution; in cases where competitive equilibrium is dynamically inefficient (r<n) debt effects may reverse or be ambiguous
